The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102558 doi: medRxiv preprint Proteins were extracted from a small amount of naso-oropharyngeal samples, fast tryptic 131 digestion was applied and followed with a 60 min reverse-phase separation. NanoLC-MSMS 132 analysis provided the identification of 207 protein groups with high confidence (<1% FDR). 133

Statistical analysis done in Progenesis QIP software identified 17 proteins to be statistically 134 significantly expressed in patients' naso-oropharyngeal samples (Table 1) (which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102558 doi: medRxiv preprint Degranulation mechanism is part of the innate immune system which is necessary for the 156 fight against infection and provides the neutrophils with the necessary tools. In COVID-19 157 patients, it was argued that the interlink between the innate and adaptive immune system may 158 serine protease enzyme that is involved in granulocyte differentiation is expressed in the 173 neutrophil granulocytes [9] . Promyelocyte proliferation is inhibited by PR3 expression that 174 leads to neutrophil differentiation [10] . PRTN3 has various catalytic functions like cleavage 175 of extracellular matrix and antiinflammatory proteins and activation of cytokines. MPO which 176 is also expressed in neutrophil granulocytes can generate chlorine oxidants to ill infection 177 agents [11] . Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) autoantibodies specifically 178 target azurophil proteins like PRTN3 and MPO and their role in numerous autoimmune 179 disorders are discussed but primary focuses is systemic vasculitis where blood vessels are 180 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102558 doi: medRxiv preprint 8 destroyed via inflammation [10] . ANCA with cytoplasmic staining pattern against PRTN3 (c-181 ANCA) is seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) whereas perinuclear staining 182 pattern against MPO (p-ANCA) is seen in eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis 183 (EGPA), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), and pauci-immune idiopathic crescentic 184 glomerulonephritis [12] . Vascular endothelium in GPA patients are damaged by neutrophils 185 that actively participate in autoimmune response [13] . Vasculitis risk in patients increases 186

with PRTN3 positive neutrophils [14] . PRTN3 is expressed on the surface of the neutrophils 187 and the ANCAs that target PRTN3 causes pro-inflammatory effects [9] . The increased 188 PRTN3 and MPO production in the neutrophils of COVID-19 patients are the target for anti-189 neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. Increased PRTN3 was shown to have a negative effect on 190 the resolution of inflammation that causes immune system deregulation [15] . In a mouse 191 study, ANCAs that target MPO were injected through IV and it triggered extra capillary 192 glomerulonephritis [16] . Neutrophil apoptosis is necessary in the resolution of inflammation 193 [17] . The resolution of inflammation and tissue repair processes are aided by the cytokines 194 released from macrophages during phagocytosis of the neutrophils [10] . The dysregulation in 195 the macrophage orchestrated phagocytosis and neutrophil apoptosis mechanisms leads to 196 inflammation [18] . Patients with ANCA originated vasculitis are more prone to apoptosis as a 197 result of ANCA activation [19] . PRTN3 is reported as a signal that sustains the inflammatory 198 microenvironment [9] . The overexpression of PRTN3 observed in COVID-19 patients may 199 impair the resolution of inflammation during neutrophil apoptosis. It is argued that the 200 recruited neutrophils to the site of inflammation get activated and the release of uncontrolled 201 mediators may cause tissue damage. The inflammation seen in vasculitis is converted to 202 necrotizing vasculitis via the release of toxic mediators due to early neutrophil apoptosis and 203 also by decreased level of apoptotic neutrophil clearance by macrophages [10] . PRTN3 was 204 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102558 doi: medRxiv preprint 9 also reported to interfere with complement protein C1-q mediated clearance of Apoptotic 205 Cells [20] . 206

NETosis is a type of programmed cell death where neutrophil extracellular traps are formed 207 [21] . NETs were identified in 2004 and they are often overlooked as drivers of severe 208 pathogenic inflammation [22] . NETs have pathogen killing properties and include strands of 209 DNA wrapped with histones and are enriched with neutrophil proteins like MPO and ELANE 210 [23] . PRTN3, ELANE, and CTSG are coined as neutrophil serine proteases (NSP) and have 211 tissue degrading and microbial killing effects [24] . NSP's active role in neutrophil-associated 212 lung inflammatory and tissue-destructive diseases has been reported [25] . Increased 213 expressions of PRTN3, ELANE, and CTSG was reported in COPD patients [26] . In a mouse 214 model study ELANE or PRTN3 was introduced to the trachea which caused tissue destruction 215 and enlargement in airspace [27] . ELANA expression was also implicated in the impairment 216 of host defense resulting in a decrease in mucociliary clearance of bacteria and also pathogens 217 phagocytosis [28] . CD2, CD4, and CD8 can be cleaved on the surface of T-cells by ELANE 218 and CTSG that dysregulate T-cell Function [29] . It was reported that patients that lack alpha-1 219 antitrypsin (α1-Pi) which s the physiological inhibitor of PRTN3 and ELANE carries a high 220 risk of developing emphysema [30] . Azurophil granules also carry Cathepsin D which was 221 reported to be up-regulated in the pulmonary macrophages in a mouse model of cigarette 222 smoking [31] . Severe COPD cases exhibited MPO positive cells as a signal of neutrophil 223 activation [32] . On the other hand in a mouse model of influenza it was shown that the 224 inflammation damage was reduced by the absence of MPO [33] . IL-32, a proinflammatory 225 cytokine with four isoforms, cleavage by PRTN3 propagates cytokine activity and triggers IL-226 1beta, TNF-alpha, IL-6, and chemokines [34] . It was argued that the targeted inhibition of 227 PR3 or silencing of IL-32 by an inactive form of PRTN3 may halt the IL-32 driven immune 228 dysregulation [34] . NSPs like ELANE, CTSG, and PRTN3 can cleave pro-IL-1beta to 229 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102558 doi: medRxiv preprint bioactive IL-1beta [35] . Caspase-1/Interleukin-1 converting enzyme (ICE) cleaves proteins 230 like precursors of the inflammatory cytokines interleukin 1β and interleukin 18 into their 231 mature biologically active forms [36] and CTSG regulates Caspase-1 in this pathway [37] . 232 ICE has an active role in cell immunity as an initiator of inflammatory response so once 233 activated it triggers the formation of active IL-1beta which is secreted from the cell that symptoms. Also targeting NETs to dampen the out-of-control host response as a treatment 252 may increase the survival rate by reducing the number of patients who require mechanical 253 ventilation in ICU. We posit here that excess NETs may elicit the severe multi-organ 254 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF0.text: respiratory distress syndrome-associated coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) also 59 known as COVID-19 first appeared in Wuhan, Hubei, China in December 2019, and now it is 60 widespread around the World. The replication of the virus is through the human airway 61 epithelial cells where it targets the receptors of human Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme 2 62 (ACE-2). The high mortality observed in COVID-19 is associated with severe acute 63 respiratory distress and systemic coagulopathy. Many COVID-19 patients show a postponed 64 onset of respiratory issues but then develop into more severe situations. We wanted to 65 investigate the molecular changes in the COVID-19 patients' naso-oropharyngeal swab 66 samples via comparison to the proteome of PCR negative cases. Our goal is to find pathways 67 associated with the site of infection through proteomics analysis. 17 statistically significant 68 protein alterations lead us specifically to neutrophil degranulation pathways. 69 During airway infections, Neutrophils are the first wave of defense that also defines the 70 disease outcome. Neutrophils have multiple functions in viral infections such as inactivation 71 of the virus, achieved by phagocytosis, ROS production, proteolytic enzyme release, NET 72 activation (NETosis, Neutrophil Extracellular Traps). Neutrophils also interact with immune 73 cells and secreting cytokines participate in eliciting an antiviral response. 74 Neutrophil granulocytes express several enzymes linked to controlling host infection. As the 75 cytotoxic molecules are released from the granules they have an impact on the inflammatory 76 response. Such adverse molecules cause severe damage to the host where it exhibits itself as 77 perivascular infiltrates around the capillaries in the lungs as observed in SARS-CoV-2 78 patients. The identified up-regulated proteins Neutrophil Elastase, Azurocidin, 79

FIGREF1.text: of the significantly altered protein levels between COVID-19 positive and 138 negative patients' naso-oropharyngeal swab samples were analyzed using the STRING online 139 database. The PPI network obtained, contained 17 differentially expressed proteins with 15 140 nodes (disconnected nodes were not shown) and 14 edges as shown in Figure 1A. The main 141 cluster includes Neutrophil Elastase (ELANE), Azurocidin (AZU1), Myeloperoxidase 142 (MPO), Myeloblastin (PRTN3), Cathepsin G (CTSG) and Transcobalamine-1 (TCN1). The 143 abundance of these proteins were found to be increased in COVID-19 positive patient 144 samples compared to negative ones. REACTOME pathway enrichment analyses of the 145 differentially expressed proteins were performed. Nine of the proteins were primarily 146 associated with the immune system pathway. Proteins clustered in the PPI network were 147 mainly enriched in the neutrophile degranulation pathway (HSA-6798695, FDR=2.01E-7) 148 which is a subpathway of the innate immune system (a vital role in airway infections and may also define the disease outcome and 152 carry out various functions in viral infections ranging from phagocytosis, degranulation to the 153 generation of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) [3]. Neutrophils also interact with the 154 immune cells and secreting cytokines participate in eliciting the antiviral response. 155 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF2.text: the severity and mortality of the disease [4]. Granules in neutrophils carry 159 synthesized antimicrobial molecules and the content differs depending on the stage of 160 maturation [5], depending on their contents they are named as azurophilic, gelatinase 161 granules, specific, and secretory vesicles [6]. 162 163 In SARS-CoV-2 patients' naso-oropharyngeal samples, we have identified azurophilic 164 granule (AG) proteins like Myeloperoxidase (MPO), elastase (ELANE), cathepsin G (CTSG), 165 azurocidin 1 (AZU1) and proteinase 3 (PRTN3) to be highly overexpressed. Azurophilic 166 neutrophils undergo limited exocytosis when activated [7] and their primary role is believed 167 to be killing and degradation of engulfed microbes in the phagolysosome [8]. Although 168 neutrophil degranulation having a positive impact on clearance of SARS-CoV-2 from the 169 nasopharynx, in the inflammation microenvironment the process is broken and may lead to 170 tissue damage by the secreted molecules from the granules. naso-oropharyngeal samples of 171 COVID-19 patients demonstrate an increased level of both PRTN3 and MPO. PRTN3, a 172

FIGREF3.text: 234 induces inflammation in the neighboring cells [38]. It was recently reported that infection in 235 COVID-19 patients with acute respiratory syndrome showed release of the pro-inflammatory 236 cytokines like IL-1beta and IL-6 [39]. Through the available literature, we can see that the up-237 regulation of various proteins observed in the naso-oropharyngeal swab samples of COVID-238 19 patients is tightly interconnected with the immune response. of various proteins in SARS-CoV-2 infected patients' naso-oropharyngeal 242 samples depict the molecular changes that govern the host antiviral defense system. The 243 available literature for many respiratory diseases are very helpful in linking altered protein 244 expressions to viral pathogenesis. Obtained data provided us an important view of SARS-245 CoV-2 molecular changes on the protein level in the infection site. Statistically significant 246 protein alterations of PRTN3, MPO, ELANE, CTSG, AZU1, and TCN1 dysregulation is 247 important in the early phases of infection and may be targets for anti-SARS-CoV-2 248 therapeutics. Further research may show a link between the level of these proteins with 249 disease severity and may be used as prognostic markers. Modulating the dysregulated proteins 250 like PRTN3 or MPO may promote an anti-inflammatory response to alleviate SARS-CoV-2 251
